Completeness for vector lattices

Youssef Azouzi
Research Laboratory of Algebra, Topology, Arithmetic, and Order
Faculty of Mathematical, Physical and Natural Sciences of Tunis
Tunis-El Manar University, 2092-El Manar, Tunisia
Abstract

The notion of unboundedly order converges has been recieved recently a particular attention by several authors. The main result of the present paper shows that the notion is efficient and deserves that care. It states that a vector lattice is universally complete if and only if it is unboundedly order complete. Another notion of completeness

will be treated is the notion of sup-completion introduced by Donner.

1 Introduction

This paper deals with various notions of completeness for a vector lattice and studies the connection between them. We will pay a particular attention to the notion of unbounded order convergence and then to the unbounded order completeness. A normed space is said to be complete if every Cauchy sequence is norm convergent. In contrast to this definition, notions as Dedekind completeness and universal completeness are often defined via the existence of supremum for certain families. A Dedekind complete vector lattice X𝑋X is also called order complete and this is very meaningful because the order completeness is equivalent to the fact that order Cauchy nets are order convergent. One can ask whether or not there is an analogous characterization of universal completeness. In the recent paper [8], the authors proved that under some extra condition a vector lattice is universal complete if and only if every u​o𝑢𝑜uo-Cauchy net is u​o𝑢𝑜uo-convergent. The main result of the present paper (Theorem 15) states that this equivalence is still true without any further assumption. This result shows how the notion of unboundedly order convergence is both deep and natural.

Another notion of completeness, which concerns cones, will also be treated here and connected to the previous notions: the notion of sup-completion. It has been introduced by Donner in [6] and used by Grobler in his recent papers. It will play here a crucial role in the proof of our main theorem.

The structure of the paper is as follows. The next section (Section 2) is devoted to the notion of sup-completion mentioned above. Every order complete vector lattice X𝑋X has a sup-completion Xs.subscript𝑋𝑠X_{s}. Roughly speaking, Xssubscript𝑋𝑠X_{s} plays the same role for X𝑋X as ℝ∞=ℝ∪{∞}subscriptℝℝ\mathbb{R}_{\infty}=\mathbb{R}\cup\left\{\infty\right\} does for ℝℝ\mathbb{R}. In this section we provide the most important properties of the cone Xssubscript𝑋𝑠X_{s} and prove some new results. The most useful for us is Theorem 11 which characterizes elements in Xssubscript𝑋𝑠X_{s} that do not belong to Xu,superscript𝑋𝑢X^{u}, where Xusuperscript𝑋𝑢X^{u} is the universal completion of X.𝑋X. In section 3 we prove the main Theorem of this paper which states that a vector lattice is universally complete if and only if it is u​o𝑢𝑜uo-complete. This section contains several applications of this result. In particular, it helps to simplify some proofs in [9] and [11]. The last part of this section is devoted to the σ𝜎\sigma-completeness.

2 Sup-completion.

Throughout this section, X𝑋X stands for an order complete vector lattice and its universal completion is denoted by Xu.superscript𝑋𝑢X^{u}. We know from [6] that there exists a unique (up to isomorphisms) order complete cone, called the sup-completion of X𝑋X and denoted by Xs,subscript𝑋𝑠X_{s}, with the following properties:

  1. 1.

    X𝑋X is the set of invertible elements in Xssubscript𝑋𝑠X_{s} coinciding algebraic and order structures.

  2. 2.

    For every y∈Xs𝑦subscript𝑋𝑠y\in X_{s} we have y=sup{x∈X:x≤y}.𝑦supremumconditional-set𝑥𝑋𝑥𝑦y=\sup\left\{x\in X:x\leq y\right\}.

  3. 3.

    We have x+f∧y=(x+f)∧(x+y)𝑥𝑓𝑦𝑥𝑓𝑥𝑦x+f\wedge y=\left(x+f\right)\wedge\left(x+y\right) whenever x,y∈Xs,f∈Xformulae-sequence𝑥𝑦subscript𝑋𝑠𝑓𝑋x,y\in X_{s},f\in X. If, in addition, X𝑋X has a weak order unit e𝑒e then x=sup(k​e∧x)𝑥supremum𝑘𝑒𝑥x=\sup\left(ke\wedge x\right) for all 0≤x∈Xs.0𝑥subscript𝑋𝑠0\leq x\in X_{s}.

  4. 4.

    If x∈X𝑥𝑋x\in X and y∈Xs𝑦subscript𝑋𝑠y\in X_{s} satisfy y≤x𝑦𝑥y\leq x then y∈X.𝑦𝑋y\in X.

  5. 5.

    Xssubscript𝑋𝑠X_{s} has a biggest element.

  6. 6.

    For any two non-empty subsets A,B⊂Xs𝐴𝐵subscript𝑋𝑠A,B\subset X_{s} satisfying supA=supBsupremum𝐴supremum𝐵\sup A=\sup B the equality

    supa∈A(a∧x)=supb∈B(b∧x)subscriptsupremum𝑎𝐴𝑎𝑥subscriptsupremum𝑏𝐵𝑏𝑥\sup\limits_{a\in A}\left(a\wedge x\right)=\sup\limits_{b\in B}\left(b\wedge x\right)

    holds for every x∈X.𝑥𝑋x\in X. In particular if m=supA𝑚supremum𝐴m=\sup A then

    m∧x=supa∈A(a∧x).𝑚𝑥subscriptsupremum𝑎𝐴𝑎𝑥m\wedge x=\sup\limits_{a\in A}\left(a\wedge x\right).

We shall throughout refer to these properties as P1, P2, etc. A cone satisfying properties P1-P3) is said to be imbedded for X.𝑋X. An imbedded cone is said to be tight provided that it satisfies property P4). We refer the reader to [6] for further details on the subject.

It follows from the construction of the sup-completion, that if A,B⊂X𝐴𝐵𝑋A,B\subset X then sup(A+B)=supA+supBsupremum𝐴𝐵supremum𝐴supremum𝐵\sup\left(A+B\right)=\sup A+\sup B in Xssubscript𝑋𝑠X_{s} (see the proof of [6, Theorem 1.4]). The following lemma tells us that Xssubscript𝑋𝑠X_{s} has the Riesz Decomposition Property.

It is also useful to observe that the following Birkhoff Inequality holds: If a,b∈X,c∈Xsformulae-sequence𝑎𝑏𝑋𝑐subscript𝑋𝑠a,b\in X,c\in X_{s} then

Definition 2

Let X,Y𝑋𝑌X,Y be two order complete vector lattices with sup-completions Xssubscript𝑋𝑠X_{s} and Yssubscript𝑌𝑠Y_{s}, respectively. We say that an increasing map g:Xs⟶Ys:𝑔⟶subscript𝑋𝑠subscript𝑌𝑠g:X_{s}\longrightarrow Y_{s} is (left) order continuous if g​(xα)↑g​(x)↑𝑔subscript𝑥𝛼𝑔𝑥g\left(x_{\alpha}\right)\uparrow g\left(x\right) whenever xα↑x.↑subscript𝑥𝛼𝑥x_{\alpha}\uparrow x.

Lemma 4

Proposition 5

Let X𝑋X be an order complete vector lattice with weak unit element e𝑒e and T𝑇T a conditional expectation with T​e=e.𝑇𝑒𝑒Te=e. Let x𝑥x and y𝑦y be two positive elements in Xssubscript𝑋𝑠X_{s} with y∈R​(T),𝑦𝑅𝑇y\in R\left(T\right), the range of T.𝑇T. Then

    x∈Xs∖Xu𝑥subscript𝑋𝑠superscript𝑋𝑢x\in X_{s}\setminus X^{u}

A very useful consequence of the Theorem 11 is the following.

Corollary 12

Let X𝑋X be a vector lattice and x∈Xs∖Xu.𝑥subscript𝑋𝑠superscript𝑋𝑢x\in X_{s}\setminus X^{u}. Then there exists a∈X𝑎𝑋a\in X such that x≥t​a>0𝑥𝑡𝑎0x\geq ta>0 for all real t>0.𝑡0t>0.

The construction of the cone Xssubscript𝑋𝑠X_{s} is a little complicated and it seems interesting and helpful to know more about its relationship with the space Xu.superscript𝑋𝑢X^{u}. An interesting information is given below.

Proposition 13

Let X𝑋X be an order complete vector lattice then the positive cone of Xusuperscript𝑋𝑢X^{u} is contained in Xs.subscript𝑋𝑠X_{s}.

Proof. Fix a positive element x∈Xu𝑥superscript𝑋𝑢x\in X^{u} and choose an increasing net in X𝑋X such that xα↑x.↑subscript𝑥𝛼𝑥x_{\alpha}\uparrow x. Let us define y𝑦y to be the supremum of the net (xα)subscript𝑥𝛼\left(x_{\alpha}\right) in Xs.subscript𝑋𝑠X_{s}. We claim that y=x.𝑦𝑥y=x. First, we show that y∈Xu.𝑦superscript𝑋𝑢y\in X^{u}. Otherwise, according to Corollary 12 there is an element a∈X𝑎𝑋a\in X such that y≥n​a>0𝑦𝑛𝑎0y\geq na>0 for all integer n.𝑛n. Now observe that the following equality

sup(xα∧n​a)=x∧n​asupremumsubscript𝑥𝛼𝑛𝑎𝑥𝑛𝑎\sup\left(x_{\alpha}\wedge na\right)=x\wedge na

holds in Xusuperscript𝑋𝑢X^{u} and then in X𝑋X since X𝑋X is regular in Xu.superscript𝑋𝑢X^{u}. Moreover, property P6) yields

n​a=n​a∧y=sup(xα∧n​a).𝑛𝑎𝑛𝑎𝑦supremumsubscript𝑥𝛼𝑛𝑎na=na\wedge y=\sup\left(x_{\alpha}\wedge na\right).

Thus we get x≥n​a>0𝑥𝑛𝑎0x\geq na>0 for all n,𝑛n, which is impossible. So y∈Xu𝑦superscript𝑋𝑢y\in X^{u} as claimed and then y≥x.𝑦𝑥y\geq x. Now if this inequality is strict then there is 0<u∈X0𝑢𝑋0<u\in X such that y≥x+u𝑦𝑥𝑢y\geq x+u (because X𝑋X is order dense in Xusuperscript𝑋𝑢X^{u}). It follows that y−u≥xα𝑦𝑢subscript𝑥𝛼y-u\geq x_{\alpha} for all α.𝛼\alpha. But since y−u∈Xs𝑦𝑢subscript𝑋𝑠y-u\in X_{s} we get a again a contradiction, and the proof is finished.   

In the last part of this section we shall make some remarks about the natural domain of a conditional expectation. Consider an order complete vector lattice X𝑋X with weak unit e.𝑒e. We recall that a conditional expectation operator is an order continuous strictly positive projection on X𝑋X, with its range R​(T)𝑅𝑇R\left(T\right) is an order complete vector sublattice and with T​e=e.𝑇𝑒𝑒Te=e. It was shown in [7] that, for any conditional expectation T𝑇T on X𝑋X, there exists a largest vector sublattice of Xusuperscript𝑋𝑢X^{u} called the natural domain of T𝑇T, to which T𝑇T extends uniquely to a conditional expectation. The domain of T𝑇T is denoted by L1​(T)superscript𝐿1𝑇L^{1}\left(T\right) and defined, as in [7], in the following manner: Let D𝐷D be the set of elements x𝑥x in X+usuperscriptsubscript𝑋𝑢X_{+}^{u} for which there is a net (xα)subscript𝑥𝛼\left(x_{\alpha}\right) in X𝑋X such that xα↑x↑subscript𝑥𝛼𝑥x_{\alpha}\uparrow x and (T​xα)𝑇subscript𝑥𝛼\left(Tx_{\alpha}\right) is bounded in Xu.superscript𝑋𝑢X^{u}. Afterwards put T​x=supT​xα∈Xu𝑇𝑥supremum𝑇subscript𝑥𝛼superscript𝑋𝑢Tx=\sup Tx_{\alpha}\in X^{u} for x∈D𝑥𝐷x\in D and L1​(T)=D−D.superscript𝐿1𝑇𝐷𝐷L^{1}\left(T\right)=D-D. Of course, it has been proved that T𝑇T is well defined on D𝐷D and can be extended in a natural way to its domain. It is worth noting that the range of this extended conditional expectation enjoys the nice property of being an f𝑓f-algebra [5, Theorem 3.1]. This was also noticed by Grobler in [13] where he proved that if the conditional expectation T𝑇T with range ℱℱ\mathcal{F} is extended to its domain then its range is equal to ℱusuperscriptℱ𝑢\mathcal{F}^{u}, which is actually an f𝑓f-algebra. In this paper Grobler suggested another approach to define the domain of T𝑇T using the sup-completion Xssubscript𝑋𝑠X_{s}. Although it is not explicitly mentioned, it is understood that this approach leads to the same definition introduced in [7]. The justifications given by Grobler for these facts are somehow quick and there are some missing details (see [13, Proposition 2.1]). We provide here an alternative proof. Following Grobler we say that an element 0≤x∈Xs0𝑥subscript𝑋𝑠0\leq x\in X_{s} is in the domain of T𝑇T if T​x:=supT​xα∈Xuassign𝑇𝑥supremum𝑇subscript𝑥𝛼superscript𝑋𝑢Tx:=\sup Tx_{\alpha}\in X^{u} where (xα)subscript𝑥𝛼\left(x_{\alpha}\right) is any increasing net in X𝑋X such that xα↑x.↑subscript𝑥𝛼𝑥x_{\alpha}\uparrow x. If A𝐴A denotes the set of such elements one can prove that A𝐴A is contained in Xusuperscript𝑋𝑢X^{u} and then de set

domT=A−A.dom𝑇𝐴𝐴\operatorname*{dom}T=A-A.

It will be enough to prove that the set A𝐴A is in fact the set dom(τ)dom𝜏\operatorname*{dom}\left(\tau\right) defined in [7] and denoted above by D.𝐷D. Assume by contradiction that x∈A∖Xu.𝑥𝐴superscript𝑋𝑢x\in A\setminus X^{u}. Then there exists u>0𝑢0u>0 such that x≥n​u𝑥𝑛𝑢x\geq nu for all n∈ℕ𝑛ℕn\in\mathbb{N} and then T​x≥n​T​u.𝑇𝑥𝑛𝑇𝑢Tx\geq nTu. So T​u=0𝑇𝑢0Tu=0 which contradicts the fact that T𝑇T is strictly positive. Now inclusion D⊂A𝐷𝐴D\subset A follows from Proposition 13.

3 Universal completion and uo-complete.

We show in this section that a vector lattice X𝑋X is universally complete if and only if it is uo-complete. This answers an open problem in [8] and offers another reason that the notion of unboundedly order convergence deserves the particular attention that it recieved recently by many authors (see [10, 9, 11, 8] and the refenrences cited there). Let first recall some definitions. A net (xα)α∈Asubscriptsubscript𝑥𝛼𝛼𝐴\left(x_{\alpha}\right)_{\alpha\in A} in a vector lattice X𝑋X is said to be order convergent to x𝑥x (and we write xα​⟶𝑜​xsubscript𝑥𝛼𝑜⟶𝑥x_{\alpha}\overset{o}{\longrightarrow}x) if there exists a net (yβ)β∈Bsubscriptsubscript𝑦𝛽𝛽𝐵\left(y_{\beta}\right)_{\beta\in B} such that yβ↓0↓subscript𝑦𝛽0y_{\beta}\downarrow 0 and for each β∈B𝛽𝐵\beta\in B there exists αβ∈Asubscript𝛼𝛽𝐴\alpha_{\beta}\in A satisfying |xα−x|≤yβsubscript𝑥𝛼𝑥subscript𝑦𝛽\left|x_{\alpha}-x\right|\leq y_{\beta} for all α≥αβ.𝛼subscript𝛼𝛽\alpha\geq\alpha_{\beta}. A net (xα)subscript𝑥𝛼\left(x_{\alpha}\right) is said to converge in unbounded order to x,𝑥x, and we write xα​⟶u​o​x,subscript𝑥𝛼𝑢𝑜⟶𝑥x_{\alpha}\overset{uo}{\longrightarrow}x, if |xα−x|∧y​⟶𝑜​0subscript𝑥𝛼𝑥𝑦𝑜⟶0\left|x_{\alpha}-x\right|\wedge y\overset{o}{\longrightarrow}0 for every y∈X+𝑦subscript𝑋y\in X_{+} It should be noted that xα​⟶u​o​xsubscript𝑥𝛼𝑢𝑜⟶𝑥x_{\alpha}\overset{uo}{\longrightarrow}x if and only if (xα∧b)∨a​⟶𝑜​(x∧b)∨asubscript𝑥𝛼𝑏𝑎𝑜⟶𝑥𝑏𝑎\left(x_{\alpha}\wedge b\right)\vee a\overset{o}{\longrightarrow}\left(x\wedge b\right)\vee a for all a≤0≤b.𝑎0𝑏a\leq 0\leq b. This can be reduced for positive nets to the following

xα∧y​⟶𝑜​x∧y​ for all ​y∈X+.subscript𝑥𝛼𝑦𝑜⟶𝑥𝑦 for all 𝑦subscript𝑋x_{\alpha}\wedge y\overset{o}{\longrightarrow}x\wedge y\text{ for all }y\in X_{+}.

A net (xα)subscript𝑥𝛼\left(x_{\alpha}\right) is said to be order Cauchy if the net (xα−xβ)(α,β)subscriptsubscript𝑥𝛼subscript𝑥𝛽𝛼𝛽\left(x_{\alpha}-x_{\beta}\right)_{\left(\alpha,\beta\right)} converges in order to zero;.and it is uo-Cauchy if the net (xα−xβ)(α,β)subscriptsubscript𝑥𝛼subscript𝑥𝛽𝛼𝛽\left(x_{\alpha}-x_{\beta}\right)_{\left(\alpha,\beta\right)} uo-converges to zero.

3.1 The main result

In [8] Li and Chen proved the following

Proposition 14

Let X𝑋X be an order complete vector lattice.

  1. 1.

    If X𝑋X is uo-complete then X𝑋X is universally complete.

  2. 2.

    If X𝑋X is universally complete and has the countable sup property then X𝑋X is uo-complete.

It is quite easy to prove, as we shall see, that the first assertion holds without the assumption of order completeness. Moreover, the converse of 1) also holds, showing that the converse is true without requiring any further assumption on the space. Our main result of this section is the following:

Theorem 15

A vector lattice X𝑋X is universally complete if and only if is uo-complete.

Proof. Assume first that X𝑋X is uo-complete and consider an order Cauchy net (xα)subscript𝑥𝛼\left(x_{\alpha}\right) in X.𝑋X. Then (xα)subscript𝑥𝛼\left(x_{\alpha}\right) is uo-Cauchy and hence it is uo-convergent to some x.𝑥x. But since (xα)α∈Asubscriptsubscript𝑥𝛼𝛼𝐴\left(x_{\alpha}\right)_{\alpha\in A} is order Cauchy it has a bounded tail and then it converges in order to x.𝑥x. This shows that X𝑋X is order complete. We will prove now that X𝑋X is laterally complete. This fact is proved in [8] as noted above and we provide here an alternative proof which involves the sup-completion Xs.subscript𝑋𝑠X_{s}. Let (xα)α∈Asubscriptsubscript𝑥𝛼𝛼𝐴\left(x_{\alpha}\right)_{\alpha\in A} be a family of mutually disjoint positive vectors in X𝑋X and define yF=supα∈Fxαsubscript𝑦𝐹subscriptsupremum𝛼𝐹subscript𝑥𝛼y_{F}=\sup\limits_{\alpha\in F}x_{\alpha} for every finite subset F𝐹F of A.𝐴A. Then xF↑x=supxα∈Xs↑subscript𝑥𝐹𝑥supremumsubscript𝑥𝛼subscript𝑋𝑠x_{F}\uparrow x=\sup x_{\alpha}\in X_{s} and it is enough to show that x∈X.𝑥𝑋x\in X. Observe that for every u∈X+𝑢subscript𝑋u\in X_{+} we have that xF∧u↑x∧u∈X↑subscript𝑥𝐹𝑢𝑥𝑢𝑋x_{F}\wedge u\uparrow x\wedge u\in X because x∧u≤u∈X.𝑥𝑢𝑢𝑋x\wedge u\leq u\in X. It follows that (xF)subscript𝑥𝐹\left(x_{F}\right) is uo-Cauchy in X𝑋X so xFsubscript𝑥𝐹x_{F} is uo-convergent to some x′∈X+.superscript𝑥′subscript𝑋x^{\prime}\in X_{+}. But since (xF)subscript𝑥𝐹\left(x_{F}\right) is increasing, x′=supxF=xsuperscript𝑥′supremumsubscript𝑥𝐹𝑥x^{\prime}=\sup x_{F}=x and we are done.

Conversely, assume that X𝑋X is universally complete and consider a uo-Cauchy net (xα)α∈Asubscriptsubscript𝑥𝛼𝛼𝐴\left(x_{\alpha}\right)_{\alpha\in A} in X.𝑋X. We have to show that (xα)subscript𝑥𝛼\left(x_{\alpha}\right) is uo-convergent. By considering the nets (xα+)superscriptsubscript𝑥𝛼\left(x_{\alpha}^{+}\right) and (xα−)superscriptsubscript𝑥𝛼\left(x_{\alpha}^{-}\right) we may assume that (xα)subscript𝑥𝛼\left(x_{\alpha}\right) is a positive net. For each a∈X+,𝑎subscript𝑋a\in X_{+}, the net (xα∧a)subscript𝑥𝛼𝑎\left(x_{\alpha}\wedge a\right) is order convergent to some limit ℓa∈X+.subscriptℓ𝑎subscript𝑋\ell_{a}\in X_{+}.We put ℓ=supa∈X+ℓa∈Xs.ℓsubscriptsupremum𝑎subscript𝑋subscriptℓ𝑎subscript𝑋𝑠\ell=\sup\limits_{a\in X_{+}}\ell_{a}\in X_{s}. The proof will be completed by two steps.

ℓ∧a=supu∈X+ℓu∧a=supu∈X+(ℓu∧a).ℓ𝑎subscriptsupremum𝑢subscript𝑋subscriptℓ𝑢𝑎subscriptsupremum𝑢subscript𝑋subscriptℓ𝑢𝑎\ell\wedge a=\sup\limits_{u\in X_{+}}\ell_{u}\wedge a=\sup\limits_{u\in X_{+}}\left(\ell_{u}\wedge a\right).

Hence there exists b≥0𝑏0b\geq 0 such that

ℓb∧a>ℓb∧a∧ℓa=ℓb∧ℓa.subscriptℓ𝑏𝑎subscriptℓ𝑏𝑎subscriptℓ𝑎subscriptℓ𝑏subscriptℓ𝑎\ell_{b}\wedge a>\ell_{b}\wedge a\wedge\ell_{a}=\ell_{b}\wedge\ell_{a}.

and on the other hand

3.2 Some applications

Next, we give some applications of Theorem 15. The first result will be useful to develop short proofs of some of the results of [10, 9, 11].

Theorem 16

Let X𝑋X be an order continuous Banach lattice with dual X∗.superscript𝑋∗X^{\ast}.

  1. (i)

    If (φα)subscript𝜑𝛼\left(\varphi_{\alpha}\right) is a uo-Cauchy net in X∗superscript𝑋∗X^{\ast} that converges in the weak∗ topology σ​(X∗,X)𝜎superscript𝑋∗𝑋\sigma(X^{\ast},X) is uo-convergent to the same limit.

  2. (ii)

    If (xα)subscript𝑥𝛼\left(x_{\alpha}\right) is a uo-Cauchy net in X𝑋X that converges weakly then it is uo-convergent to the same limit.

Proof. (i) As usual, we may assume that (φα)subscript𝜑𝛼\left(\varphi_{\alpha}\right) is positive. By Theorem 15, φα​⟶u​o​ψsubscript𝜑𝛼𝑢𝑜⟶𝜓\varphi_{\alpha}\overset{uo}{\longrightarrow}\psi in (X∗)usuperscriptsuperscript𝑋∗𝑢\left(X^{\ast}\right)^{u} for some ψ∈(X∗)u𝜓superscriptsuperscript𝑋∗𝑢\psi\in\left(X^{\ast}\right)^{u} and it will be enough to establish that ψ=φ.𝜓𝜑\psi=\varphi. To this end, in view of property P4) of Xssubscript𝑋𝑠X_{s} (see Section 2), we need only to show that ψ∧h=φ𝜓ℎ𝜑\psi\wedge h=\varphi for all h∈X∗ℎsuperscript𝑋∗h\in X^{\ast} with h≥φ.ℎ𝜑h\geq\varphi. Now, pick hℎh in X∗superscript𝑋∗X^{\ast} with h≥φ.ℎ𝜑h\geq\varphi. Since φn​⟶w∗​φsubscript𝜑𝑛superscript𝑤∗⟶𝜑\varphi_{n}\overset{w^{\ast}}{\longrightarrow}\varphi it is easily seen that

φα∧h​⟶w∗​φ∧h=φ.subscript𝜑𝛼ℎsuperscript𝑤∗⟶𝜑ℎ𝜑\varphi_{\alpha}\wedge h\overset{w^{\ast}}{\longrightarrow}\varphi\wedge h=\varphi.

On the other hand φn∧h​⟶𝑜​ψ∧hsubscript𝜑𝑛ℎ𝑜⟶𝜓ℎ\varphi_{n}\wedge h\overset{o}{\longrightarrow}\psi\wedge h and by [9, Theorem 2.1] φα∧h​⟶w∗​ψ∧h.subscript𝜑𝛼ℎsuperscript𝑤∗⟶𝜓ℎ\varphi_{\alpha}\wedge h\overset{w^{\ast}}{\longrightarrow}\psi\wedge h. Hence ψ∧h=φ𝜓ℎ𝜑\psi\wedge h=\varphi as required.

(ii) Consider a net (xα)subscript𝑥𝛼\left(x_{\alpha}\right) with xα​⟶𝑤​xsubscript𝑥𝛼𝑤⟶𝑥x_{\alpha}\overset{w}{\longrightarrow}x and assule as usual that (xα)subscript𝑥𝛼\left(x_{\alpha}\right) is positive. Using Theorem 15 we know that xα​⟶u​o​zsubscript𝑥𝛼𝑢𝑜⟶𝑧x_{\alpha}\overset{uo}{\longrightarrow}z for some z∈Xu.𝑧superscript𝑋𝑢z\in X^{u}. Let y∈X+,𝑦superscript𝑋y\in X^{+}, then xα∧y​⟶𝑜​z∧ysubscript𝑥𝛼𝑦𝑜⟶𝑧𝑦x_{\alpha}\wedge y\overset{o}{\longrightarrow}z\wedge y in Xusuperscript𝑋𝑢X^{u} and then in X𝑋X (since X𝑋X is regular in Xusuperscript𝑋𝑢X^{u} and order complete). Using the fact that X𝑋X is order continuous we get xα∧y​⟶∥∥​z∧yx_{\alpha}\wedge y\overset{\left\|{}\right\|}{\longrightarrow}z\wedge y and so xα∧y​⟶𝑤​z∧y.subscript𝑥𝛼𝑦𝑤⟶𝑧𝑦x_{\alpha}\wedge y\overset{w}{\longrightarrow}z\wedge y. On the other hand in view of xα​⟶𝑤​x,subscript𝑥𝛼𝑤⟶𝑥x_{\alpha}\overset{w}{\longrightarrow}x, it follows easily that xα∧y​⟶𝑤​x∧ysubscript𝑥𝛼𝑦𝑤⟶𝑥𝑦x_{\alpha}\wedge y\overset{w}{\longrightarrow}x\wedge y for every y∈X+.𝑦subscript𝑋y\in X_{+}. Hence x∧y=z∧y𝑥𝑦𝑧𝑦x\wedge y=z\wedge y for all y∈X+,𝑦subscript𝑋y\in X_{+}, which gives the equality x=z𝑥𝑧x=z and completes the proof.   

As an immediate consequence of Theorem 16 we get the following results.

Theorem 17

[9, Theorem 2.2] Let X𝑋X be an order continuous Banach lattice. Then any norm bounded uo-Cauchy net in X∗superscript𝑋∗X^{\ast} converges in uo and |σ|​(X∗,X)𝜎superscript𝑋∗𝑋|\sigma|(X^{\ast},X) to the same limit.

Theorem 18

[11, Theorem 4.3] Let X𝑋X be an order continuous Banach lattice. Then every relatively weakly compact uo-Cauchy net converges uo-and |σ|​(X,X∗)𝜎𝑋superscript𝑋∗\left|\sigma\right|\left(X,X^{\ast}\right) to the same limit.

Proof. If (xα)subscript𝑥𝛼\left(x_{\alpha}\right) is relatively weakly compact then it has a subnet (xβ)subscript𝑥𝛽\left(x_{\beta}\right) weakly convergent to some x∈X.𝑥𝑋x\in X. According to Theorem 16 xβ​⟶u​o​xsubscript𝑥𝛽𝑢𝑜⟶𝑥x_{\beta}\overset{uo}{\longrightarrow}x and then xα​⟶u​o​xsubscript𝑥𝛼𝑢𝑜⟶𝑥x_{\alpha}\overset{uo}{\longrightarrow}x because (xα)subscript𝑥𝛼\left(x_{\alpha}\right) is uo-convergent in Xu.superscript𝑋𝑢X^{u}.   

Theorem 19

[11, Theorem 4.7] Let X𝑋X be an order continuous Banach lattice. The following statements are equivalent.

  1. 1.

    X𝑋X is a KB-space.

  2. 2.

    X𝑋X is boundedly uo-complete.

  3. 3.

    X𝑋X is sequentially uo-complete.

Proof. We need only to prove that (1) ⟹\implies(2). Let (xα)subscript𝑥𝛼\left(x_{\alpha}\right) be a norm bounded uo-Cauchy net. By considering (xα±)superscriptsubscript𝑥𝛼plus-or-minus\left(x_{\alpha}^{\pm}\right) we may assume that (xα)subscript𝑥𝛼\left(x_{\alpha}\right) is positive. In view of Theorem 15 we know that xα​⟶u​o​xsubscript𝑥𝛼𝑢𝑜⟶𝑥x_{\alpha}\overset{uo}{\longrightarrow}x for some x∈Xu.𝑥superscript𝑋𝑢x\in X^{u}. Since X𝑋X is order complete and regular in Xusuperscript𝑋𝑢X^{u} it follows from [10, Theorem 3.2] that xα∧a​⟶𝑜​x∧asubscript𝑥𝛼𝑎𝑜⟶𝑥𝑎x_{\alpha}\wedge a\overset{o}{\longrightarrow}x\wedge a in X𝑋X for all a∈X.𝑎𝑋a\in X. Now observe that ‖x∧a‖≤sup‖xα‖<∞.norm𝑥𝑎supremumnormsubscript𝑥𝛼\left\|x\wedge a\right\|\leq\sup\left\|x_{\alpha}\right\|<\infty. Hence the net (x∧a)a∈X+subscript𝑥𝑎𝑎subscript𝑋\left(x\wedge a\right)_{a\in X_{+}} is norm bounded and increasing in the KB-space X.𝑋X. It follows that x=supa∈Xx∧a∈X𝑥subscriptsupremum𝑎𝑋𝑥𝑎𝑋x=\sup\limits_{a\in X}x\wedge a\in X and we are done.   

Recall that a Banach lattice is said to satisfy the weak Fatou property if there is a real r>0𝑟0r>0 such that for every increasing net (xα)subscript𝑥𝛼\left(x_{\alpha}\right) with the supremum x∈X𝑥𝑋x\in X it follows that ‖x‖≤r​supα‖xα‖.norm𝑥𝑟subscriptsupremum𝛼normsubscript𝑥𝛼\left\|x\right\|\leq r\sup\limits_{\alpha}\left\|x_{\alpha}\right\|. Since there is a Banach lattice X𝑋X with weak Fatou property such that Xn~={0}superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑛~absent0X_{n}^{\widetilde{}}=\left\{0\right\} the next theorem improves [8, Theorem 2.3]. Theorem 15 will be used again to get a short proof.

Theorem 20

Let (xα)subscript𝑥𝛼(x_{\alpha}) be a norm bounded positive increasing net in a Banach lattice X𝑋X. Suppose that X𝑋X satisfies one of the following conditions: (i) Xn∼superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑛similar-toX_{n}^{\sim} separates points of X;𝑋X; (ii) X𝑋X satisfies the weak Fatou property. Then (xα)subscript𝑥𝛼(x_{\alpha}) is uo-Cauchy in X𝑋X.

Proof. Let x=supxα∈Xs.𝑥supremumsubscript𝑥𝛼subscript𝑋𝑠x=\sup x_{\alpha}\in X_{s}. It is sufficient to show that x∈Xu.𝑥superscript𝑋𝑢x\in X^{u}. Assume by contradiction that it is not the case, then by Corollary 12 that there exists an element a∈X𝑎𝑋a\in X such that x≥t​a>0𝑥𝑡𝑎0x\geq ta>0 for all real t>0.𝑡0t>0. It follows that

xα∧n​a↑n​a​ in ​X.↑subscript𝑥𝛼𝑛𝑎𝑛𝑎 in 𝑋x_{\alpha}\wedge na\uparrow na\text{ in }X. (1)

If (i) is satisfied, then there is 0≤φ∈Xn~0𝜑superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑛~absent0\leq\varphi\in X_{n}^{\widetilde{}} such that φ​(a)>0.𝜑𝑎0\varphi\left(a\right)>0. It follows from φ​(xα∧n​a)↑n​φ​(a)↑𝜑subscript𝑥𝛼𝑛𝑎𝑛𝜑𝑎\varphi\left(x_{\alpha}\wedge na\right)\uparrow n\varphi\left(a\right) that n​φ​(a)≤M​‖φ‖𝑛𝜑𝑎𝑀norm𝜑n\varphi\left(a\right)\leq M\left\|\varphi\right\| for all n,𝑛n, which is impossible.
If ii) is satisfied then in virtu of 1 we obtain n​‖a‖≤C​sup‖xα‖𝑛norm𝑎𝐶supremumnormsubscript𝑥𝛼n\left\|a\right\|\leq C\sup\left\|x_{\alpha}\right\| for all n,𝑛n, which is also impossible. This completes the proof.   

3.3 The σ𝜎\sigma-completeness

It was proved [10, Corollary 3.12] that a uo-null sequence in X𝑋X is o-null Xusuperscript𝑋𝑢X^{u}. A concrete example in [8, Example 2.6] shows that this result fails for nets. We can ask the following questions

Problem 21

Suppose that X𝑋X is an arbitrary order complete but not laterally complete vector lattice. Is there a uo-Cauchy net in X𝑋X that fails to be order convergent in Xusuperscript𝑋𝑢X^{u}?

Problem 22

Is it true that if X𝑋X is a vector lattice for which order convergence and uo-convergence agree for sequences then X𝑋X is universally σ𝜎\sigma-complete?

So far, we do not have an answer to the first question. However, the answer to the second question is negative as the next example shows.

Example 23

Consider the space X𝑋X of real sequences x=(xn)n≥1𝑥subscriptsubscript𝑥𝑛𝑛1x=\left(x_{n}\right)_{n\geq 1} such that x2​n=x2​n+1subscript𝑥2𝑛subscript𝑥2𝑛1x_{2n}=x_{2n+1} for n𝑛n enough large. Then X𝑋X is a vector lattice which is not laterally σ𝜎\sigma-complete. Indeed the sequence (yn)superscript𝑦𝑛\left(y^{n}\right) define by

yn={enif ​n​ is even0if ​n​ is oddsuperscript𝑦𝑛casessuperscript𝑒𝑛if 𝑛 is even0if 𝑛 is oddy^{n}=\left\{\begin{array}[c]{cc}e^{n}&\text{if }n\text{ is even}\\ 0&\text{if }n\text{ is odd}\end{array}\right.

has no supremum in X,𝑋X, where ensuperscript𝑒𝑛e^{n} is the sequence defined by ekn=1superscriptsubscript𝑒𝑘𝑛1e_{k}^{n}=1 if k=n𝑘𝑛k=n and ekn=0superscriptsubscript𝑒𝑘𝑛0e_{k}^{n}=0 otherwise. However, it is easy to see that a sequence (yn)superscript𝑦𝑛\left(y^{n}\right) in X𝑋X is uo-null iff it is o-null.

In spite of the last example which give a negative answer to our question we have the following ‘positive’ result.

Proposition 24

For an order σ𝜎\sigma-complete vector lattice X𝑋X the following are equivalent

  1. 1.

    X𝑋X is universally σ𝜎\sigma-complete;

  2. 2.

    A sequence in X𝑋X is uo-null if only if it is o-null.

The implication i) ⟹\implies ii) follows from [10, Corollary 3.12]. Assume conversely that ii) is satisfied and consider a disjoint positive sequence in X.𝑋X. According to [10, Corollary 3.6] xn​⟶u​o​0subscript𝑥𝑛𝑢𝑜⟶0x_{n}\overset{uo}{\longrightarrow}0 and then by ii) xn​⟶𝑜​0.subscript𝑥𝑛𝑜⟶0x_{n}\overset{o}{\longrightarrow}0. So (xn)subscript𝑥𝑛\left(x_{n}\right) is bounded. This shows that the sequence yn=x1∨…∨xnsubscript𝑦𝑛subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛y_{n}=x_{1}\vee...\vee x_{n} is also bounded and then has a supremum as X𝑋X is order σ𝜎\sigma-complete. This proves that X𝑋X is laterally σ𝜎\sigma-complete and ends the proof.

It has been proved in [10, Lemma 2.11] that if Y𝑌Y is a regular order complete sublattice of a vector lattice X𝑋X then every net in Y𝑌Y that is order convergent to some x𝑥x in X𝑋X is order convergent in Y𝑌Y to the same limit. Similarly we can prove the following.

Lemma 25

Let Y𝑌Y be a vector sublattice of a vector lattice X.𝑋X. Assume that Y𝑌Y is regular in X𝑋X and order σ𝜎\sigma-complete. If (yn)⊂Ysubscript𝑦𝑛𝑌\left(y_{n}\right)\subset Y and yn​⟶x𝑜subscript𝑦𝑛𝑜⟶absent𝑥y_{n}\overset{o}{\longrightarrow x} in X𝑋X then x∈Y𝑥𝑌x\in Y and yn​⟶𝑜​xsubscript𝑦𝑛𝑜⟶𝑥y_{n}\overset{o}{\longrightarrow}x in Y.𝑌Y.

The next Theorem is a ”variant” of Theorem 15.

Theorem 26

The vector lattice X𝑋X is universally σ𝜎\sigma-complete if and only if is sequentially uo-complete.

Proof. It follows from [10, Theorem 3.10] that every universally σ𝜎\sigma-complete vector lattice is sequentially uo-complete. Now assume that X𝑋X is sequentially uo-complete. If (xn)subscript𝑥𝑛\left(x_{n}\right) is bounded above then the sequence (yn=x1∨…∨xn)subscript𝑦𝑛subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛\left(y_{n}=x_{1}\vee...\vee x_{n}\right) converges in Xu,superscript𝑋𝑢X^{u}, say yn↑x∈Xu.↑subscript𝑦𝑛𝑥superscript𝑋𝑢y_{n}\uparrow x\in X^{u}. It follows then that (yn)subscript𝑦𝑛\left(y_{n}\right) is o-Cauchy so it is uo-Cauchy in Xu.superscript𝑋𝑢X^{u}. Since X𝑋X is regular in Xusuperscript𝑋𝑢X^{u} it follows from [10, Theorem 3.2] that (yn)subscript𝑦𝑛\left(y_{n}\right) is uo-Cauchy in X𝑋X and so it is uo-convergent in X𝑋X to some y∈X.𝑦𝑋y\in X. It is easy now to see that y=x=supxn.𝑦𝑥supremumsubscript𝑥𝑛y=x=\sup x_{n}. Assume now that (xn)subscript𝑥𝑛\left(x_{n}\right) is a sequence of positive disjoint elements in X.𝑋X. Let yn=x1∨…∨xn.subscript𝑦𝑛subscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛y_{n}=x_{1}\vee...\vee x_{n}. Then yn↑y=supxn∈Xu.↑subscript𝑦𝑛𝑦supremumsubscript𝑥𝑛superscript𝑋𝑢y_{n}\uparrow y=\sup x_{n}\in X^{u}. By the same way we prove that y∈X.𝑦𝑋y\in X.
